questions.question_text: In which OSI layer does IS-IS operate?

discussion.content: Is this Exam equivalent to current cisco exam ENSLD 300-420?

The intermediate systems communicate between each other by using Layer 2 of the OSI model directly


Cisco Book of CCDP ARCH
Look at RFC 1142, there details abouts OSI Data Link layer.

From WIkipedia

While OSPF was natively built to route IP and is itself a Layer 3 protocol that runs on top of IP, IS-IS is an OSI Layer 2 protocol.
Correct answer is Layer 3. It is a routing protocol.
Probably B. The distribution switches are not VSS'ed and each keeps its control plane independent

comments.content: Better considering the wording, I'd go with C as well. The control planes are already there, they are not formed because of vPC.

questions.question_text: What is an advantage of using the vPC feature in a data center environment?

choices.C: The control plane and management plane remain separate.
choices.B: Multiple instances of control plane are formed.
choices.D: Cisco FabricPath technology does not have to be configured.

questions.question_text: Which option is a benefit of the vPC+ feature?

choices.A: Cisco FabricPath is not required in the network domain.
choices.C: Nonfabric devices, such as a server or a classic Ethernet switch, can be connected to two fabric switches that are configured with vPC.
choices.D: The control plane and management plane are combined into one logical plane.
choices.B: This feature provides fault domain separation.

discussion.content:
C
Like OSPF, IS-IS is also a link-state protocol using Dijkstra’s algorithm, in which each router has topology information for its area

questions.question_text: Which algorithm does IS-IS use to determine the shortest path through a network?

discussion.content:
For sure the answer is "in-band" so it is not neither "B" nor "D" at all.
But I am trying to understand why "Layer 3 in-band” and not "Layer 2 in-band”?

I don't agree with you.
the correct answer is B 
 In-band (Cisco NAC Server is always in-line with user traffic) 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/security/nac-appliance-clean-access/product_data_sheet0900aecd802da1b5.html

i thnk is C
For NAC Appliance Server to work, it must be physically or logically inline between the clients and their destinations during the initial posture assessment and remediation. After the clients pass the posture assessment, NAC Appliance Server can be removed from the dataflow (out of band) or remain in the dataflow (in band). The next chapter will discuss these different options in detail.

questions.question_text: The network engineering team is interested in deploying NAC within the enterprise network to enhance security. What deployment model should be used if the team requests that the NAC be logically inline with clients?
